alert.note: Alert for Chuska Mountains; Espanola Valley; Far Northwest Highlands; Jemez Mountains; Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Northwest Highlands; Northwest Plateau; San Francisco River Valley; Santa Fe Metro Area; Southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Southwest Mountains; Tusas Mountains Including Chama; Upper Rio Grande Valley; West Central Highlands; West Central Mountains; West Central Plateau (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 25 at 5:57AM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...SNOW AND BLOWING SNOW ACROSS NORTHERN AND WESTERN NM SUNDAY... Snow and strong to damaging winds will return to northern and western New Mexico on Sunday as a storm system races across the state. An associated cold front will enter western New Mexico Sunday morning and will reach the Texas border by late afternoon. Strong southwest winds will become westerly behind the front and increase in speed. Additionally, a mix of rain and snow along the frontal boundary should rapidly change to snow as much colder temperatures filter into the area. Snow amounts of 1 to 2 inches will be common across western NM, while the Northern Mountains may pick up 2 to 5 inches. Wind gusts of 40 to 60 mph are expected which will create areas of blowing snow and reduced visibility. It`s possible that whiteout conditions will be briefly observed behind the front. Road conditions may deteriorate quickly, especially across higher elevations. Hazardous crosswinds are also expected on north to south oriented roadways, including U.S. Highway 491 and State Highway 371. In particular, these winds will impact high-profile vehicles. Residents and travelers through northern and western New Mexico should remain cautiously aware of these changing weather conditions. Stay updated on the forecast at weather.gov/abq or through your preferred media outlet, and consider alternate travel plans if possible.
